summary.p: Single folio; Shelfmark: Al-15; Writing surface: parchment; Qurʾānic text: Q 6:19-31; Lines per page: 13; Script style: kūfī, variation of the D.Va type; Dimensions: 330 x 238 mm; Estimated date of production: 750-850.

Originally Al-15 is probably from the same codex as HC.MS.03168 and HC.MS.03113 from the Qatar National Library (Doha) and sxm/ag. 2529 from the Georgian National Museum. A single folio fragment from the same manuscript is also held in Lausanne, Switzerland.

The Library of Congress has classified the flesh side (fol. 1 v in this catalogue) as the recto, possibly because it is the hair side with the better preserved text. According to the text, fol. 1r precedes the text of fol. 1v, which led us to classify the two pages in reverse, contrary to the Library of Congress. The folio containing the text from Q 6:19-25 is labelled as recto, while the folio containing Q 6:25-31 is labelled as verso.
Link to the document in Library of Congress: https://www.loc.gov/item/2019714725/.

support.p: The text on fol. 1v is better preserved as it is on the hair side of the parchment. Fol. 1r is the flesh side. Quire structure: not known.

Text Division: There are single, fifth and tenth verse separators. Single verse separators consist of small gold rosettes. The fifth verse separator (preserved on fol. 1v line 2) is a gold painted letter hāʾ, a numeral verse separator representing the number 5 in the Abjad counting system. The tenth verse separator on fol. 1r is a larger gold painted medallion with the word ʿišrūn written within the circle, standing for the 20th verse of the Surah al-ʾAnʿām. Red, green, yellow and blue colours are used to paint in the medallion. Gold ink is also used for the ornaments. On fol. 1r the word niṣf for 'half' is written in gold on the left margin to mark the ǧuzʾ (part) of the text. On fol. 1v the second taʿšīr marker is attested, a medallion with a different design to fol. 1r. with the word ṯalāṯūn for the number thirty. (Salome Beridze)

summary.p: The script of this Qurʾān fragment represents the kūfī script style D being close to the D.Va group with elements of D.I/D.II as these subgroups are very similar (Déroche 1983: PN 112-116), (Déroche 1992: PN 44-45). The letter ʾalif in the independent form has a long lower return with an upward curve. The letter ǧīm in the medial form lies on the base line so that the letter before it is placed a little bit higher. In the final or independent position ǧīm has a tail that curves back to the head of the letter close to the line, similar to the D.I/D.II group. The letter ṭāʾ in the final or independent position is similar to those in the D.Va group. ʿAyn initially resembles the D.Va group. In middle position, the letter shows a vertical right hand antenna which remains vertical in final position as well. Qāf in its final or independent form shows a U-shaped tail that goes backwards as in D.II group. The letter mīm in middle and final position is closer to D.II and D.III group. In both positions the letter lies rather flat on the line, in final position it has a short flat tail. Nūn in final and independent position has a long body and the head is shorter than in D.I, being closer to D.III. Hāʾ in the medial position is placed on the base line, the two eyes are mostly defined. The shape of the letter, which resembles a drop is close to the D.Va group. The lām-ʾalif ligature also resembles D.Va and D.I group, but the lām is much thinner than ʾalif and curves towards it.
Unlike Déroche, we use the term kūfī for pragmatic reasons - a term which is attested only after the 10th century.

Diacritics: Diacritica of the script are marked by oblique dashes in the same dark brown ink as the main text, mostly, the letters bāʾ and nūn in final or independent position are marked. Vocalisation is indicated by red and green dots. Some lines show mašq, horizontal stretching of the letters, a technique used to achieve a regular arrangement of letters within a line. (Salome Beridze)
